awd_titl_txt: Sustaining Undergraduate Classroom and Career Excellence for STEM Students (SUCCESS) Project
awd_abstract_narration:
In Nebraska, seven of the twelve industry clusters that drive the state economy are STEM-related. However, Nebraska STEM employers struggle to employ and retain highly qualified, technically skilled employees, citing "limited workforce availability" as the primary disadvantage to business growth statewide. Doane College's Sustaining Undergraduate Classroom and Career Excellence for STEM Students (SUCCESS) Project will award scholarships to 24 academically talented students with financial need in the college's biology, biochemistry, chemistry, environmental science, or physics program. Through increasing enrollment in STEM majors and connecting students to local STEM industries, the project will address Nebraska's need for a highly qualified STEM workforce.

The technical merit of this project lies in its plan to design, implement, assess, and advance practices that support STEM student success, such as STEM living and learning communities, Four-Year Graduation Guarantees, common coursework structures, STEM workshops, and undergraduate research experiences. Guided by a highly qualified PI team, and with strong institutional support, the SUCCESS project will evaluate STEM recruitment activities in order to advance knowledge regarding which activities are most successful at increasing STEM student postsecondary enrollment. Moreover, the project will build on past and current EPSCoR funding to increase the number and quality of research opportunities for STEM students, as well as opportunities for STEM students to participate and present at professional STEM conferences. Evaluation findings will be disseminated within the Doane community and to other postsecondary institutions and STEM professionals in order to advance the knowledge and practice of STEM student recruitment, retention to graduation, and STEM career preparation and placement, thus contributing to the knowledge base about undergraduate scholarship projects of this type and underlying elements that make them successful.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Over the duration of this award, fourty-two Scholars in four cohorts received scholarships through this program; 23 scholars received four years of scholarship and 9 Scholars received one or two years of scholarship funding. Ten scholars began the program, but did not complete it. Two Scholars with no unmet need completed four years of the program. All twenty-eight Scholars who remained in the program graduated - all within four years. This represents a 74% four-year graduation rate (28 graduates of 38 students participating in the program, not including the Year 7 scholarship recipients). The Scholars in each target major included 18 in biology, two in biochemistry, one in chemistry, three in engineering, three in environmental science, and one double major in biology and environmental science. The average college GPA of graduating Scholars was 3.6. Over half of the Scholar graduates (16 or 57%) went into STEM careers or graduate programs. Fourteen Scholars secured STEM jobs in industries throughout Nebraska serving the regional economy. Two Scholars matriculated into STEM Ph.D. programs (University of Notre Dame and Washington State University). Nine Scholars went into medical fields and professional programs (32%), nearly all of them in Nebraska. Three Scholars went into non-STEM graduate programs (two MBA and one vet school). Of the six Year 7 one-time scholarship recipients, four graduated in May 2022 and two are continuing their studies at Doane in Fall 2022. Three of the four graduates secured STEM jobs in industry and one is preparing for application to pharmacy school.

Graduating Scholars, including the four Year 7 one-time scholarship recipients, were diverse (47% women, 13% URM, 44% FGen, 100% low-income with unmet financial need, and 57% from rural or very rural communities). Eighteen graduating Scholars (56%) participated in externally funded STEM research in addition to the capstone research they completed within their major, presented at regional and national conferences and contributed to publications. Three SUCCESS program interventions have been institutionalized: the living-learning community (which is being expanded to other student affinity groups), the STEM LAR101 section, and the STEM Visit Day.


Last Modified: 06/01/2022
Modified by: Tessa L Durham Brooks
